items.title: Bekerduel tussen De Treffers en NEC uitgesteld
Moyes eyes Europe on anniversary of Everton return: â€˜This has been good for meâ€™
items.summary: Despite recent stumbles, manager is confident â€˜the club is getting itself back togetherâ€™ and his enthusiasm for the job remains intact David Moyes, face puce with anger and swearing under his breath, did not resemble a man contented in his work as he dissected Evertonâ€™s disappointing draw with Wolves. As the first anniversary of his return to Everton approaches, however, that is precisely how Moyes feels. â€œIt has made me go again,â€ he says of the only job that could have tempted him back to the Premier League frontline. The 62-year-old has mellowed with the years but his incandescent reaction to Michael Keaneâ€™s red card â€“ after Wednesdayâ€™s game and when Evertonâ€™s appeal was rejected on Friday â€“ showed the fire and fight burn as intensely as ever. There could be more eruptions ahead. Continue reading...

items.title: Van Persie verwelkomt twee spelers en heeft zorgen over veiligheid Feyenoord-fans
items.summary: Feyenoord kan zondag weer beschikken over Sem Steijn en Givairo Read. Trainer Robin van Persie gaf aan dat zijn selectie na het trainingskamp weer een stuk fitter oogt en dat de twee terugkeerde spelers klaarstaan voor speeltijd. Daarnaast houdt de trainer rekening met de weersomstandigheden en maakt hij zich vooral zorgen om de veiligheid van de meegereisde supporters.

items.title: Smart, independent and in demand â€¦ but would Glasner be a good fit for Manchester United?
items.summary: The Austrian has thrived at teams who do not expect to have much of the ball but this style may not work at Old Trafford where possession is expected Oliver Glasner has shown a penchant for one-liners, as well a 3-4-2-1 formation, since he took over at Crystal Palace almost two years ago. The Austrian declared he was â€œnot David Copperfieldâ€ in his first press conference and usually has a saying for whatever situation Palace are in, such as declaring they must not be â€œone-hit wondersâ€ after winning the FA Cup. It was therefore no surprise to find Glasner had come prepared when he played a straight bat to questions about his future this week after Ruben Amorimâ€™s sacking by Manchester United. â€œIâ€™m not a gambler,â€ he said when asked to comment on the fact he is the bookmakersâ€™ favourite to take over at Old Trafford in the summer. Continue reading...

items.title: New outfits and snow disruption: inside Macclesfield before jackpot FA Cup tie
items.summary: Phoenix club are lowest-ranked in third round and could have sold hundreds more tickets for visit of holders Crystal Palace In the corner of a small dressing room Macclesfieldâ€™s manager, John Rooney, and his assistant Francis Jeffers are locked in serious conversation. The pair scribble on tiny pieces of paper, planning one final training session before Saturdayâ€™s FA Cup third-round tie with the holders, Crystal Palace. The kit man, Ged Coyne, clutching his traditional plastic bag full of supermarket goodies, arrives and immediately the mood lightens, shoulders drop and smiles arrive. Next door music blasts out as the squad prepare for their morningâ€™s work. The surrounds are unfamiliar, snow necessitating a late venue switch to Manchester Metropolitan Universityâ€™s Platt Lane complex. Continue reading...

items.title: Semenyo completes circuitous rise from schoolboy rejection to Manchester City arrival
items.summary: Bournemouth will find it hard to replace a player at the peak of his powers, an attacker polished up perfectly for the elite Antoine Semenyoâ€™s rise is a reminder the big clubsâ€™ scouting systems are not infallible, that not all players will flower at the same time. Fulham, Arsenal, Crystal Palace, Millwall, Reading and Tottenham rejected the schoolboy Semenyo. At 15, he took a yearâ€™s absence from the game. A decade on, a circuitous route to the top alights at Manchester City, who beat a queue of big hitters to his signature. Bournemouthâ€™s ability to find talent the elite passed over continues to prove profitable. Pep Guardiolaâ€™s squad has another player who pairs physical power with a high skill level. It also adds a long-throw specialist to the armoury; City are towards the bottom of the metrics in that voguish category. Continue reading...
